body:
See individual commit messages for more details.  I only skipped a tiny handful of tests.  In other cases test files were split up so that I could skip _only_ those cases that depend on `long double` functions on Cygwin (pending any better resolution to that issue).

In other cases a few tests were slightly rewritten to work correctly, and a few fixes to the test runner itself were needed.

I don't think there is any continuous integration being done for Cython on Windows, or Cygwin in particular.  If there's any interest I would be willing to work on setting that up and maintaining it.

comment_data.body: `DL_EXPORT` vs. `DLL_EXPORT` feels like a typo. A more common name would be `HAS_DL_EXPORT`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -35,10 +35,19 @@ p2 = f2
 p3 = f3
 p4 = f4
 
+
+######## callingconvention.h ########
+
+#define DLL_EXPORT
+#include "external_callingconvention.h"
+
+
 ######## external_callingconvention.h ########
 
 #ifndef DL_IMPORT
   #define DL_IMPORT(t) t
+#elif defined(DLL_EXPORT)
+  #define DL_IMPORT(t) DL_EXPORT(t)

comment_data.body: You might be misunderstanding the purpose of this but I'm not sure. Here `DLL_EXPORT` is a flag indicating that the header is being used to share declarations between translations units that will be statically linked (in which case all objects should be declared `DL_EXPORT`), as opposed to providing a declaration for an object that will be loaded by dynamic linking to a DLL (in which case it should be `DL_IMPORT`).  I.e. the whole discussion in #360.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -35,10 +35,19 @@ p2 = f2
 p3 = f3
 p4 = f4
 
+
+######## callingconvention.h ########
+
+#define DLL_EXPORT
+#include "external_callingconvention.h"
+
+
 ######## external_callingconvention.h ########
 
 #ifndef DL_IMPORT
   #define DL_IMPORT(t) t
+#elif defined(DLL_EXPORT)
+  #define DL_IMPORT(t) DL_EXPORT(t)

comment_data.body: The way I've rewritten this, it might be clearer if `callingconvention,.h` were named `callingconvention_internal.h`, in that it is meant only for use when compiling the module, not when linking to it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -35,10 +35,19 @@ p2 = f2
 p3 = f3
 p4 = f4
 
+
+######## callingconvention.h ########
+
+#define DLL_EXPORT
+#include "external_callingconvention.h"
+
+
 ######## external_callingconvention.h ########
 
 #ifndef DL_IMPORT
   #define DL_IMPORT(t) t
+#elif defined(DLL_EXPORT)
+  #define DL_IMPORT(t) DL_EXPORT(t)

comment_data.body: Ok, then what about `USE_DL_EXPORT` or `EXPORT_SYMBOLS` ? Or anything else that makes it clear what the purpose is.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -35,10 +35,19 @@ p2 = f2

 #ifndef DL_IMPORT
   #define DL_IMPORT(t) t
+#elif defined(DLL_EXPORT)
+  #define DL_IMPORT(t) DL_EXPORT(t)

comment_data.body: I looks like because of the change I made here, although I removed the `-std=c89` flag, quite a few more warnings are being generated in the Travis-CI builds than there were previously due to the `-pedantic` flag, which was previously not being added due to the fact that `compiler != 'gcc'`.  I don't know if we particularly care about `-pedantic` or not--the `ISO C90 does not support ‘long long’ [-Wlong-long]` are especially annoying.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -826,8 +858,8 @@ def run_distutils(self, test_directory, module, workdir, incdir,
             ext_compile_flags = CFLAGS[:]
             compiler = COMPILER or sysconfig.get_config_var('CC')
 
-            if self.language == 'c' and compiler == 'gcc':
-                ext_compile_flags.extend(['-std=c89', '-pedantic'])
+            if self.language == 'c' and 'gcc' in compiler:
+                ext_compile_flags.append('-pedantic')

comment_data.body: In any case this seems to be what caused the build to fail--all the `long long` warnings cause the log length limit of 4MB to be exceeded and the job is terminated prematurely.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -826,8 +858,8 @@ def run_distutils(self, test_directory, module, workdir, incdir,
             ext_compile_flags = CFLAGS[:]
             compiler = COMPILER or sysconfig.get_config_var('CC')
 
-            if self.language == 'c' and compiler == 'gcc':
-                ext_compile_flags.extend(['-std=c89', '-pedantic'])
+            if self.language == 'c' and 'gcc' in compiler:
+                ext_compile_flags.append('-pedantic')

comment_data.body: For better or worse `DLL_EXPORT` is the standard name for the macro that serves this purpose.

comment_data.body: I doubt that this is a C compiler option that is globally available in all supported C/C++ compilers. I'd rather change the test to use a different C function (but one with two parameters to make use of keyword arguments).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,5 +1,6 @@
 # cython: c_string_type=str
 # cython: c_string_encoding=ascii
+# distutils: extra_compile_args=-fpermissive

comment_data.body: Could we restrict this to cygwin, if it matters there? We're not currently requiring C99, so seeing those warnings would be nice.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -856,10 +856,7 @@ def run_distutils(self, test_directory, module, workdir, incdir,
                 build_extension.compiler = COMPILER
 
             ext_compile_flags = CFLAGS[:]
-            compiler = COMPILER or sysconfig.get_config_var('CC')
 
-            if self.language == 'c' and 'gcc' in compiler:
-                ext_compile_flags.append('-pedantic')

comment_data.body: Hmm, ok, I see. We currently require PY_LONG_LONG support in several places, which contradicts the intention of not requiring a "recent" C compiler. I'll respond to your mail on the mailing list.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -826,8 +858,8 @@ def run_distutils(self, test_directory, module, workdir, incdir,
             ext_compile_flags = CFLAGS[:]
             compiler = COMPILER or sysconfig.get_config_var('CC')
 
-            if self.language == 'c' and compiler == 'gcc':
-                ext_compile_flags.extend(['-std=c89', '-pedantic'])
+            if self.language == 'c' and 'gcc' in compiler:
+                ext_compile_flags.append('-pedantic')

commit.message:
Fix declarations and callingconvention tests to not incorrectly use DL_IMPORT when building the module

See https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/360#issuecomment-214420624

Use a headerfile for cfuncs.c, otherwise this test code will fail to build on Windows

See https://mail.python.org/pipermail/cython-devel/2016-April/004777.html

Test cleanup on Cygwin should avoid deleting any DLLs until the end of the test run.

This issue is particular to Cygwin since on Cygwin distutils.spawn uses os.fork(). Deleting DLLs can lead to Cygwin's fork() breaking, due to trying to load a DLL that no longer exists.  This means that the test run will use a little more disk space on Cygwin, but still allows full (or partial) cleanup at the end.

Skip tests that fail specifically on Cygwin.

Right now this is the only such test. There are other tests that generate code that uses long double math functions, but not in a way that appears to break the test.

Don't force -std=c89, as this can conflict with HAVE_LONG_LONG from Python.h

see
https://mail.python.org/pipermail/cython-devel/2016-April/004776.html

Also note better support for gcc variants that are not named 'gcc' exactly.

Fix random failures of the test common_include_dir on Windows

os.rename() could fail sometimes with a permission error; using shutil.move() instead seems to be more robust against that.
These test fails with C++ on Cygwin due to lack of long double functions. This was not a problem in plain C, but the C++ compiler is stricter about undeclared functions.  Better to skip them anyways.
c++ on Cygwin is missing the 'const char *' redefinition of strchr, and complains angrily that this test does not get the signature right, so tell it to be more permissive.
This test is broken on Windows due to the issue discussed in https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/360

title: Several fixes to get test suite passing on Cygwin
